text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised text for IRM 9.4.7, Consensual Monitoring.
9.4.7.1 is updated to change the term telephone conversations to telephonic All subsequent references to telephone conversations and telephone consensual have been changed to telephonic.

Subsection 9.4.7.2(5) is added to reflect the required use of the Criminal Investigation Management Information System (CIMIS) when requesting authorization to conduct consensual monitoring or making modifications to existing consensual monitoring authorizations.

Subsections 9.4.7.3.1(2), 9.4.7.4.1(4), and 9.4.7.5(1) are revised to reflect the required use of CIMIS when requesting authorization to conduct telephonic consensual monitoring or making modifications to existing telephonic consensual monitoring authorizations in lieu of Form 8041, Request for Authorization to Use Electronic Equipment and Consensual Monitoring. All subsequent references to Form 8041 in these subsections have been removed.
Subsection 9.4.7.4.2(1)(b) is revised to remove reference to Form 8041.
Additional revisions, deletions, and grammatical changes are made throughout the section, which did not result in substantive changes but contribute to procedural clarity.
This IRM supersedes IRM 9.4.7, Consensual Monitoring dated September 24, 2007

) The term consensual monitoring, as used herein, means the investigative ception, overhearing, or recording of a private conversation by the use of mechanical, electronic, or other devices with the consent of at least one, but not all, of the participants (as contrasted to non-consensual monitoring, no participant consents). Consensual monitoring may be used in primary subject investigations. Telephonic consensual monitoring may be used in general investigations. (
) Supervisory approval is not required for monitoring conversations with the consent of all parties to the conversation. (

) The monitoring of conversations with the consent of one of the participants may be used whenever it is both appropriate and necessary to gather evidence related to a criminal offense. However, this technique is subject to careful oversight in order to avoid any unwarranted invasion of privacy or ception of impropriety. (

) To protect the integrity of all consensual monitoring activities: a. Recordings must be preserved in their entirety, including information unrelated to the investigation. b. A record of all contacts with the subject of the monitoring request must maintained. The record must reflect all contacts with the subject, those that were not recorded. This record will include the consensual monitoring authorization number, the investigation number, the date of contact, and the subject of that contact. An explanation as to why a contact was not monitored must also be included. (

) Whenever technically feasible, the conversations overheard (whether tele- phonic or non-telephonic) will be recorded by means of a tape or similar of permanent record. Such tapes or other permanent record of the and any logs, transcripts, summaries, or memoranda together with copies of requests for approval and reports shall be specifically safeguarded against improper disclosure. A record of individuals who have had access to this material shall be maintained and retained by the custodian of the tape or permanent record. (
) Except for those devices described in paragraph (

) below, field offices may not purchase, fabricate, or have manufactured any consensual monitoring equipment or accessories without approval from the Director, Security and Technical Operations, or designee. Additionally, all equipment obtained with approval will be entered into CIMIS by the acquiring office. (

) Criminal Investigation field offices may maintain an inventory of induction in-line recording devices, or similar devices for use when consensual tele- phonic monitoring is approved. These devices may also be used to record conversations where all individuals to the conversation consent. (
) Field offices may purchase induction coils, in-line recording devices, or devices locally. (
) Use of personally-owned induction coils, in-line recording devices, or similar devices is prohibited. (

) Custodial responsibility for each monitoring device will be assigned to the Headquarters office technical representative. At the request of the SAC, the Headquarters office technical representative may reassign custodial bility over monitoring devices to a field office technical agent. This agent will maintain a control log or record showing the date each monitoring device released from storage, to whom it was assigned, and the date it was to storage. The monitoring device will be returned promptly to the custodian after its authorized use. (

) The Chief, CI, will develop and administer programs to ensure that all employees who operate or install non-telephonic consensual monitoring equipment and pen registers are adequately trained in the use and of this equipment.
